replies.author: @Mumra2K
replies.text:
Pretty much, but purely for clarification rather than any slight aimed to US or non-EU viewers. I try to be aware that not all readers are 'local to me' and thus don't subscribe to my geographical orientation. By my observation, I've seen instances where names are not unique to a country. A few examples being, London, UK vs London, Ontario vs London, Ohio.
For all I know, there's another Berlin location somewhere and it doesn't take much for me to be specific and type the additional 'Germany' at the end. I dont always do this practice, I wasn't made conscious that I do this until I read these comments. Is it overkill? Does it come across as 'mean' to some readers? Let me know, thanks!

replies.author: @Mumra2K
replies.text:
Hey Eddy, thankfully I took your initial comment to have that well meaning behind it before you clarified it but I'm glad you clarified nonetheless. The trip was wonderful, I wish I could have spent more time there to be a tourist. I spent over 6hrs in the Berlin Story Bunker (by accident!), much to the horror of my partner. I think I'm out of the dog house for that but oh my did I learn so much.

As for the Muslim question (hmmm don't feel right phrasing it like this but you know what I mean - 'your' question about Muslim assault [sic]) I entered Berlin wondering if I personally would see first hand account of an impact of the 1M Syrian refugees. I did not. What I observed, (which I offer consciously as purely anecdotal), was an established multi-cultural city in harmony showing clear integration of immigrants of probably Turkish origin. Leaving Germany, I had a new hypothesis that it would make sense that perhaps these immigrants/refugees were probably located/settled to less populated rural areas. So I still wonder how things are with their assimilation into a new 'home' given the circumstances they've found themselves in.

I dont have any problem with migrants but there doesnt seem to be any plan for these young people. they need something to do and somewhere else to go. and the problem seems almost completely centered at the train stations, as soon as you leave everything seems normal.

replies.author: @shattynatty27
replies.text:
Aksum ·ä†·ä≠·à±·àù ·ç£ ·äï·åç·à•·âµ it‚Äôs a little unfair to place all blame on the west for the destabilization of the near east/ North Africa and sub-Saharan Africa, although their is a fair amount of blame to be had. 

The instability in the Middle East and North Africa is largely domestic in origin. The protests of the Arab Spring, which evolved into the civil wars in Syria, Yemen, Libya and the general upheaval in Egypt, were directed at corruption and abuses of domestic governments. The systems of many Arab states, built on corruption/nepotism/patronage were always fragile. It‚Äôs hard to blame the west for this. Sure the US has supported many of these regimes, but what other options were available? State building? We‚Äôve seen how that works out. The Iraq War was certainly a mistake and a large contributing factor to regional instability, but in the years preceding the refugee crisis Iraq was relatively stable. The disintegration of Syria reignited the region, and neither the origin of that conflict nor the escalation can be ENTIRELY blamed of the West. Did the West contribute? Yes. Is it solely to blame? Certainly not. Gulf states and Turkey were desperate for regime change in order to bolster their influence, and Iran sought to support the Assad regime to bolster its regional power. Traditional power politics among regional powers is more responsible for the current instability than any direct Western intervention.
Yemen is a similar case. Libya is an example where western interference really screwed things up, yet the country was already in the midst of a rebellion- it‚Äôs not like NATO bombers flew into a completely stable country and removed the regime. This is a case of exacerbating instability, but not creating it. 

It‚Äôs hard to draw an direct link between any U.S./European government operations in sub-Saharan Africa and the relative instability of their states/society. I suppose one could make the argument that the legacy of colonialism left many of these nations unable to maintain any semblance of stability/economic growth, or that they entered the race so far behind the West. This seems like a fair argument to me, but we shouldn‚Äôt ignore the role played by local actors competing for power, using the government as a tool to enrich allies rather than promote the general welfare. Not to mention the problems of geography, climate, demographics that allowed Europe to dominate African territory in the first place

author: @zarathustrasserpent1850
text:
As someone who is part of the skeptic community, I really like this channel. It provides much needed criticism.

The main point of the people that you were criticizing is not to ask who is to blame. They are concerned mainly about their feeling that the problems created by the refugees are not being discussed honestly, and that European hate speech laws are preventing an honest discussion. So they can be forgiven for being more flippant about how much Merkel is actually to blame for it. But it is still important - the narrative that blames Merkel is the path that can lead one to adopting conspiracy theories about globalists, Jews etc.

Anyway, I hope we can have a dialogue in the future. Not so much about this question - I am not a European. But there's lots to talk about.

replies.author: @marxistin
replies.text:
> The DDR had 20 million undereducated, indoctrinated people and a failing economy. Germany handled the integration of East Germany.

This is such an arrogant and stupid thing to say. The education system in the DDR was very good - maybe even better than the West German one - since it was very important to them and a lot of work and money was invested into it.
And indoctrinated? Yeah, even those "undereducated" East Germans had their own critical opinions about stuff and didn't automatically believe everything the government said. You know, just like normal people. But ultimately, most people didn't even really care about politics anyway. Dude, I wish most East Germans were staunch communists but they really weren't. And people seem to forget that West Germany was very anticommunist (e.g. people active in communist circles not being allowed to be teachers) and tried to make the DDR look worse than it was (and this still shapes the way West Germans think about the DDR). You sound like you never actually talked to someone who grew up in the DDR. Also, many East Germans wouldn't agree that West Germany handled the "integration" of East Germany well.

replies.author: @swanpride
replies.text:
Here is a little fact about the DDR: The relation of Stasi informants to normal citizen was 2 to 1 (meaning, two people informing on one person). So don't give me any BS of there being any proper discussion culture, or an education system which encouraged free thinking. Which is a huge problem, because in the West German work place free thinking is encouraged. 

Look, nobody claims that everything was handled right during reunification. But what East Germans love to forget is that THEY insisted on it and THEY had a vote on it, the West Germans didn't, they had to accept it and pay up. And they did. And they don't appreciate being told then that they didn't do enough. 

East Germans really need to get over their Ostalgia and confront what the Stasi system did to them AND how many of them ended up compliant with it. They should be proud of having eventually managed to break free nevertheless, of the huge risk they took to tear down the wall. Oh, and Leipzig can be doubly proud for not just being the place of the revolution, but also managing to throw out Legida.

replies.author: @marxistin
replies.text:
"The relation of Stasi informants to normal citizen was 2 to 1"? Can you elaborate on that? Are you saying there were more Stasi informants than normal citizens?

Like I said, the education system was good because it was very organised and did lots of excursions and stuff like that. Most people who were kids in the DDR don't remember being "indoctrinated" and learning about Marxism-Leninism 24/7 but rather having a nice time, that's what I was trying to say. And while political repression isn't bad in Germany, "free thinking" is hardly encouraged if it isn't compliant with capitalist ideology. 

"THEY insisted on it and THEY had a vote on it, the West Germans didn't"? I'm not sure what you mean by that. The Einigungsvertrag (Reunification Treaty) was negotiated and accepted by both Germanys. And a 1990 survey says that 80% of West Germans wanted the reunification. (source: http://www.cap-lmu.de/aktuell/positionen/2009/deutsche-einheit.php)

And fuck Ostalgia shaming. You can appreciate something while also being critical of it. It's also very weird when some people act like East Germans who grew up in the DDR are bad people because they - often even despite having had negative experience with the Stasi - don't agree that their fatherland was a dystopic hellhole.

author: @nevermind3147
text: You are leaving out crucial points. Merkels government failed miserably at addressing rising migration numbers in previous years. 2015 did not come from nowhere, and no significant steps towards avoiding further migration were taken: refugee camps in the middle east stayed underfunded, border protection remained the problem of Greece and Italy, and her actions were widely perceived - especially among potential migrants - to be an unconditional invitation to Germany. It was not, but the state of complete disarray and pseudo-humanitarian "Willkommenskultur" could not have proven otherwise. How else do you explain migrants throwing away documents, refusing asylum in many European countries and travelling illegally to Germany and Sweden - and being successful! Cases of migrants registering multiple times to defraud the welfare systems or avoid deportation are well documented. It can very well be argued that - while her actions did not cause the crisis - they aided in prolonging it into 2016 and the following years, and that a more stringent stance on border security would have stopped this, especially combined with a campaign to create local camps and relieve the need for further movement.

author: @GodsOwnPrototype
text:
+Three Arrows
I appreciate the more detailed history & call for nuance (notably lacking in your treatment of conservatives / "right" wing people) & often accurate criticism of the lack of it or blindspots by online commentators.

However, you are obviously guilty of the same in other areas; especially the lack of context for the reasons behind both the migrant crisis & the dichotomy between western populations desires regarding both those reasons & actions regarding the resultant crisis and those of the people in positions of power & influence.

7.5 Billion People in the world, if individuals & both natural & voluntary groups cannot descriminate among them based on rational, evident and moral boundaries & the average behavioural characteristics of different populations then all is just a power struggle of might makes right under the colour of rule of law & morality.

[Each]"Society is indeed a contract. It is a partnership...not only between those who are living but those who are living, those who are dead, and those who are to be born"

I owe consideration to my ancestors and their values, sufferings & sacrifices and to my descendants and what they will inherit from me and and my relations in concentric circles moving out with diminishing concern & responsibility.

Not some abstract whole of humanity, unrelated or in reality hostile group or distant unrelated sufferer or striver from whom my kindness may be as likely insidious ingratitude or uncaring detriment to me & mine as any good to us or others.

author: @EEDIR-DK
text:
Good historical resume of the crisis. Congrats.

I do think you are undervaluing the pull-factors of public news. We had a lot people passing through our country refusing to seek asylum, because they wanted to go to Sweden. Video and interviews of the migrants saying that they were going to Sweden exactly because of higher benefits. How the criminal networks work for the human trafficking of migrants inside Europe would be very interesting to know. Migrants and refugees seem pretty informed on the benefits and official government attitudes were. 

The handling of this crisis was pretty bad. No official line from the EU, states running solo in all directions, little to no coordination between member states about asylum status really left a big and very exploitative hole for those, who were not refugees. Migrants (i.e. people, who are not fleeing from a humanitarian crisis or a conflict) did mix into crowds of genuine asylum seekers (which could  later be classified as refugees). So the problem with migrants is that it is a mixture of people, who wanted to work, flee from justice, exploit benefits and housing, and victims of modern slavery (which is sex-trafficking). Organized crime was flourishing under the breakdown of the asylum systems. 

The what to do now is a far more interesting question than pointing the finger. Easy shots at political opponents is more likely to prolong the problem than solve it. A lot of member states are running into derived problems from the migrant crisis. Sweden for example with their housing bubble, ethnic tensions (Jewish minority has it pretty bad), and local gang problems. Failure of maintaining order is also a very big issue for a country that is not used to headlines as: "Senior citizen killed by grenade". There are limits to the amount of crime a society will accept before vigilante groups pop up. We are already seeing lone-wolf "retaliation" attacks from anti-immigration movements. It is better to see how we can handle the problems feeding these movements before they get really organized. The cycle of escalation is already beginning to show up. If we are to break the cycle before it spins out of control a better understanding of the mechanics of the vigilante groups and migrant gangs are needed from the authorities.

Fixing this will take more and more extreme measures the longer we wait. Do we really want "Identity Europa" or other vigilante organizations to take the credit. It will undermine the democratic system as a whole, since then vigilantism would be preferable to a state of law (in which we have a democratic say). It is also very important to have strict guidelines on the policies, since people with good intentions can do the exact thing that would escalate or prolong a crisis. I am pretty sure NGOs for example didn't have an intention of helping human-trafficking networks.

I think you are doing yourself a disservice of not defining refugees, migrants and asylum seekers in your video. This will undoubtedly be an attack vector from your opponents. It is pretty easy for a far right political zealot to label all these groups migrants and point to the worst examples.
